reviews.text:
The "trains" side of the station is only accessible by steep stairs - there is no access for those with mobility issues or with prams etc.  Maintenance of this platform is minimal.  There is 1 screen showing the arrivals/departures but it can only be viewed by walking along the platform from the entrance, which is a pain when it then says the train is cancelled (quite regularly, as it is not a "priority line") and you have to walk back along the platform and down the stairs to find an alternative route.  Trains are scheduled to run every 30 minutes each direction, but have periods every day where cancelled.

The "trams" side is fully accessible via ramp or stairs.  Maintenance of the platform is fairly good. Trams run every 11 to 15 minutes in each direction and are generally reliable.

A very weird arrangement, two independent single tracks, one for trains, one for trams. The negative (making it not 5 stars is the fact that to transfer from one or the other, you have leave one and enter the other at street level

I don't live in Birchbeck, but I come here frequently. I like small train stations because they are easy to navigate. Personaly, my great aunt really likes this station. She is blind and she says "I really like this station because I can easily move through the station with my hands. As far as  I know, there is nothing out of place." I think people who read this review should try this station. Be sure to ignore those other 3 star reviews. P.S. When I go to this station, I usually walk, so I don't really know what parking is like.

There are two platforms at this station: one platform serves Southern trains going in both directions, and the other platforms serves trams going in both directions. 
Tram platform has an accessible ramp from street level as well as stairs. Unfortunately Southern Rail platform is accessible only by stairs.
